Name: Dollar Tree
Name_1: Family Dollar Dollar Tree stores unhygienic and chaotic workers say
Text_1:
Insider found boxes stacked up at a Dollar Tree store in Bushwick Brooklyn this during a visit this year. Insider/Brittany Chang

In February FDA inspectors found a rodent infestation at one of Family Dollar's warehouses.

Because of this Family Dollar – and its sister chain Dollar Tree – have come under scrutiny.

Workers at these chains say that pest issues have been going on for years.

It's been six months since Jayson started his job as a cashier at a Family Dollar store in Maine and he's already preparing to quit.

He's tired of working in a store that's understaffed unclean and unsafe because it's so stacked up with boxes of inventory he tells Insider.

Jayson – who did not wish to share his full name through fear of retribution but whose identity is known to Insider – is one of 12 former and current Family Dollar and Dollar Tree workers who shared similar experiences in recent conversations. The Family Dollar chain is owned by Dollar Tree.

These workers described the conditions in the chains' stores as "unhygienic and disgusting" where rodents roam in backrooms that are piled high with boxes and around stores that are rarely cleaned.

Their comments which come in the wake of an FDA investigation that unearthed a rodent infestation at one of Family Dollar's distribution centers in Arkansas and led to it temporarily closing 404 stores suggest that the rodent issues are far more widespread than at just one warehouse.

In a statement to Insider Kayleigh Campbell a spokesperson for both Dollar Tree and Family Dollar said that the company is "committed to providing safe and quality products" for customers and "complying with all applicable federal state and local occupational health and safety laws."

'To call it chaotic is an understatement'

While Jayson hasn't seen a live rodent in the shopping area of his store he has disposed of dead rats caught in traps in the stock room and come across rodent faeces.

"My location is constantly dirty floors not maintained dirt and dust everywhere and completely infested with spiders" he said.

"There is so much stuff in the back room that you can't move it all to clean even if we had the time or were asked to" he added.

Jayson said that the company knowingly understaffs its stores to keep costs down which means there aren't enough workers to empty these backrooms. But even if there were the company's chaotic inventory system means that his store is still completely overstocked all the time he said.

"They don't have enough room in the distribution centers so they'll just send us all of their junk so that it can sit in our backroom instead of theirs" he said.

A spokesperson for Family Dollar did not respond to Insider's request for comment on how its restocking process works.







Scott Mushkin CEO of consultancy firm R5 Capital witnessed these inventory pile-ups first-hand during store visits to more than 60 Dollar Tree stores between the fall of 2021 and February of this year.

In a recent conversation with Insider he said that in his 20-plus year career as a consultant to the retail industry he's never seen anything like what he encountered in these backrooms.

"To call it chaotic is really an understatement their inventory system is completely out of control from our perspective" he told Insider. "Rodents are a symptom of the disease not the disease" he said clarifying that the mountains of boxes in these backrooms were providing cover for rodents.

It paints a similar picture to what Insider found during store visits to two of Dollar Tree's Brooklyn locations in 2022 and 2018 where boxes were stacked up in the middle of the store or left to be unloaded on abandoned crates.

Mushkin told Insider that these inventory pile-ups could be caused by supply chain challenges and stock arriving at the wrong time or staffing issues because of the labor crunch. However conversations with former Dollar Tree and Family Dollar store workers who worked at these chains as far back as 2005 indicated that both piled-up stockrooms and rodent infestations have been an issue at some locations for years.

Richard Kirschke who worked for a third-party logistics company delivering stock to Family Dollar stores across the US between October 2020 and January 2021 described their backrooms as a "nightmare" where you could clearly smell rodent activity.

"It's some of the worst retail real estate" he told Insider. "They [Family Dollar] just didn't care about anything related to stores the upkeep and maintenance."

Some communities are now threatening to boycott these discount chains and saying that they're putting shoppers at risk. Dollar store chains are growing at a rapid rate in the US and are often criticized for driving out competitors in local communities by undercutting competitors on price which means that in some areas they are the only places to shop.

One former Family Dollar store worker who quit her job at a store in Freeport New York in February and who wished to remain anonymous but whose identity is known to Insider said that this is the most distressing part of the mismanagement of these stores.

"I live and shop in this community" she said. "Only after I began working at this location did I become aware of the conditions.

"When you think of the filth that my family members and neighbors – not to mention myself – have possibly consumed … it makes me sick to my stomach" she said.

Name_3: Dollar store debate: Do these discount stores — which seem to be everywhere — offer the best deals?
Name_4: Marc's opening store in Barberton's Magic City Plaza in June filling void left by Kmart
Text_4:
A Marc’s store is expected to open in Barberton in mid- to late June helping fill a gaping retail hole left after the departure of Kmart more than two years ago.

The space in the Magic City Plaza on Wooster Road North has been empty since Kmart departed in mid-December 2019. The last Kmart stores in the Akron area — in Tallmadge and North Canton — closed in February 2020.

Barberton Planning Director Trevor Hunt said the Cleveland-based discount grocery and pharmacy company fills a need in the city.

“(After) losing Kmart this really fills the void” he said on Monday.

A Big Lots store currently in the plaza will be relocated in Kmart space not used by Marc’s. Big Lots also operates a furniture store in the same plaza.

The plaza's tenants also include a Save A Lot grocery store and a Dollar Tree store.

Hunt said Marc’s entry into the city is another sign that business activity in Barberton is on the upswing after the worst of the COVID-19 pandemic.

“I think we’re seeing more and more business” he said. “The numbers are back up to where they were before.”

Hunt said his department has visited with businesses that are looking to expand and is working to keep them in Barberton.

“We have interest from a 10000-square-foot business needing double what they have” he said. “We’re working with a couple right now.”

At its peak in the 1990s Kmart operated 2400 stores with 350000 employees. Kmart will close a New Jersey store next month leaving only three in the U.S. — one each in New York New Jersey and Florida.

Marc's operates about 60 stores throughout Northeast Ohio and the state. It employees about 3000 people and had revenue of about $1.03 billion in 2021.

Name: Dominos
Name_1: Catbird's Flagship Store Is Full of Old and New Treasures | domino
Text_1:
We may earn revenue from the products available on this page and participate in affiliate programs.

When it came time for hip Brooklyn jewelry company Catbird to move its flagship to a bigger location in its Williamsburg neighborhood Leigh Plessner the brand’s chief creative officer knew exactly what design notes she wanted to hit: “Haberdashery millinery and bizarre museum displays.”

So she collaborated with Spencer Alton and Alex Bechara of design firm Alton Bechara and the team landed on giving the 1400-square-foot space an old-timey bank vintage Italian pharmacy feel. But that doesn’t mean they splurged on Murano glass (though it does appear in one lighting fixture) and expensive marble.

In fact the floors are a practical and price-friendly choice: classic Armstrong vinyl squares arranged in a black-and-white checkerboard pattern a nod to the city’s famous cookies that come in that same palette. “It’s the most basic linoleum tile you can find” Alton says before Bechara chimes in: “At first we thought we’d try to achieve a similar effect with wood but going with vinyl was the best decision we made.”

Courtesy of Leigh Plessner

From there they saved on furniture by sourcing vintage instead of new. Plessner an avid thrifter scours estate sales in Atlantic City New Jersey and shops in Bucks County Pennsylvania. Sometimes her finds appear in the store like in the case of a round metal patio table and a $30 card table with a floral design on top. On the walls an arrangement of found mirrors—most are from Etsy and impressively all but one arrived undamaged (!)—give customers a view of themselves wearing the store’s understated baubles.

And then there’s the vivid green jewelry display which was inspired by cabbage and a dress Gwyneth Paltrow wore in 1998’s Great Expectations but in IRL it’s Benjamin Moore’s Baby Fern. The shade also appears in the brand’s SoHo store connecting the two spaces. A burst of color appears on the stools which the team reupholstered in vintage French ticking.

To balance out all the vintage-feeling pieces like the knobs that came along from the former store Alton says they updated the staircase’s chunky banister staircase with a sleek railing and added new lighting and windows. And when you look at it altogether the shop is a jewel box of treasures old and new.
Name_2: Domino's Worker Shows No-Topping Pizza Order in Viral TikTok
Text_2:
Viral TikTok footage shows a Domino’s worker making a no-topping pizza order.

The worker known as Beth D (@beth_dutton) on TikTok is seen laughing in the video as she prepared the order. The pizza was devoid of toppings although Beth did add a ring of garlic sauce around its edges before cutting it.

“Some times you get strange orders at dominos” Beth wrote in the video’s caption. As of March 27 the video received about 4.4 million views.

The unusual pizza order prompted nearly 1100 comments from viewers. Several commenters referenced “None Pizza with Left Beef” an infamous meme that was born when the owner of a blog called The Sneeze ordered a pizza with no sauce no cheese and no toppings except for beef on the left half.

“where’s the left beef?” one viewer commented on the video referencing the meme.

“I thought it was gonna be none pizza left beef” another viewer commented.

“Needs left beef” another viewer said.

Some viewers said the pizza actually looked good.

“not gonna lie… that still looks good” one TikToker wrote. In response to the comment Beth wrote “It would be just like a giant breadstick.”

Other viewers said the customer may have ordered the plain pizza so they could top it themselves or because they have allergies.

“some people like to use their own sauce and toppings but prefer a better crust” one TikToker said.

Another TikToker commented “I have def ordered this. So many food allergies aversions and lifestyles in my house.”

In a comment on the video Beth explained that the pizza was ordered as a “Hawaiian minus everything” making it a $33 pie. She also wrote that she tried calling the customer to confirm the order before making it but they didn’t respond.

The Daily Dot reached out to the creator via TikTok comment and Domino’s via press email.

More fast food news
Name_3: Domino's upgrades store network ahead of more online orders and drone-delivered pizzas
Text_3:
Image: Domino's

Online orders accounted for nearly 80% of Domino's total global sales during the 2022 half-year financial results -- and the company only expects this number to grow further.

Domino's which operates in 10 markets globally has signed a deal with Macquarie Telecom to roll out NBN VoIP and SD-WAN with 4G back-up services to more than 720 Domino's stores across Australia to accommodate for the expected continued growth online.

"We want a telco infrastructure solution that's going to be capable not just for now with a large percentage of online sales … [but] will grow to the future that will be reliable for up and downstream for data and also smarter stores be it technology in-store or out of store that needs to return to base" Domino's group chief digital and experience officer Michael Gillespie told ZDNet.

The upgrade has been rolled out at 400 sites within five months with the remaining 320 sites expected to be completed in the next four months.

The decision by Domino's to upgrade its network is also ahead of potential plans by the pizza delivery company to bring drone deliveries to Australia.

"We're not just investing for a telco solution now; we're looking at the future. We obviously know with a clearer picture where we're heading … and we're validating that what we're doing is allowing a more convenient store over time" Gillespie said.

This year the company said it will be relaunching trials in New Zealand in partnership with SkyDrop formerly known as Flirtey. The pair first teamed up in 2016 and completed what they claimed was a world-first pizza drone delivery.

"Working with Flirtey and now SkyDrop we realised we practically could deliver [using drones] but the actual volume we could deliver in size of order compared to what the consumers were ordering and moving to in New Zealand there was a discrepancy" Gillespie said.

"So we needed to go back and say okay how can we work with them on a drone that can carry more and have a few other advances to get a higher commercial volume.

"We've let SkyDrop do what they do best and now they've returned with us to say we're going to get back into trialling in New Zealand. That's an exciting message and shows that what we're doing in this space really is a focus but we're not going to do it without the opportunity of validating 'Can we get to scale?'."

Gillespie believes that using drone deliveries would complement the company's existing delivery services.

"Sometimes there is a volume of orders that just surpasses what we can even hire to do at the moment. Also there's a distance for some customers that we can't [get to]; we're all about getting hot fresh pizza so can we go further and reach locations which just don't make sense for the driver to drive to or for the customer because it'll be a diminished product that is not satisfactory so robotic delivery comes into that" he said.

Improving the company's digital connectivity is also expected to underpin the company's plans to introduce more technologies in-store and upcoming revamp of its online ordering system that Gillespie described will be "slicker and faster" featuring service enhancements relating to features such as its e-commerce shopping basket.

Name_5: The Best Places to buy Blinds in 2022 | domino
Text_5:
We may earn revenue from the products available on this page and participate in affiliate programs.

Reading up on Domino’s shopping guides is like having your own personal product concierge. We do the tedious part—deep-dive research hands-on testing and tapping experts for advice—so all you have to do is hit “add to cart.” That’s why we call them Simply the Best.

Brace yourself for a barrage of tips on the best places to buy blinds. Window blinds have been used since way back when—but the pool of choices was never exactly vast. Now we see blinds and shades in a whole new way with endless styles and colors available and decorative and functional window accessories: Your blinds can easily stand alone or be paired with the best curtains. Domino’s style director Naomi deMañana has chosen those that include something for everyone: cordless for the minimalist at heart; roman style for the quiet understated shopper; and smart for the tech-loving modernist.

To help you get started we rounded up the best places to buy blinds (and some shades too) including practical budget-conscious brands and retailers that welcome customizations from cord length and hardware to tilting and light-filtering capabilities. Keep scrolling to find out where to get the best blinds for your design checklist then hang them up and applaud.

Our Favorites

Best Custom Roman Shades: Everhem

Shop

Dimensions: Customizable | Color: Flint | Material: Linen | Mounting type: Inside or out | Design: Pleated flat and relaxed

What we like: Step-by-step mounting tutorials

Up to 5 free swatches

Easy customization process Worth noting: Linings only sold in white

Why we chose it: Everhem ticks all the design boxes for customized window coverings.

This site’s detailed setup makes the design process as easy as it comes—even for the most skittish shopper. At the start to your blind and shade selection process Everhem has detailed imagery of every style it offers (choose from pleated relaxed or flat) but to take a closer look IRL the company can send up to five free swatches to your door (you just pay shipping costs). And when it’s time to iron out specifics you can find a library of informational videos and articles that answer questions about how to take accurate measurements blinds’ light-filtering capabilities and more.

Dimensions are fully customizable—you can even choose the cord-lock mechanism placement—and once your shades are ready to ship the packages are labeled to help make installation as clear-cut as possible. There’s also a price-tracking widget that helps you see the cost of your blinds from start to finish.

Best Bamboo Options: Blindster

Shop

Dimensions: Customizable | Color: Hatteras camel | Material: Bamboo wood | Mounting type: Inside or out | Design: Cordless

What we like: Prioritizes sustainability

Relatively inexpensive prices

Will refit blinds for free Worth noting: Limited styles available

Why we chose it: Sustainability meets versatility with Blindster’s window accessories.

While the inexpensive bamboo blind prices on Blindster first caught deMañana’s eye (they start at $90) we’re also huge fans of its color palettes: Shades range from rich-toned ebony to a beautifully speckled tan. After customizing dimensions you can select either a cordless or top-down design. Should you choose the deluxe bamboo you’ll have your choice of three cordless styles and two headrails. And then there’s the fit-for-free safety blanket: If your panels don’t fit for whatever reason—yes that reason could be that your blind measurements were slightly off—customers can contact Blindster within 60 days of receiving the product and they’ll remake them in the correct size for free.

Best Simple Cordless Roller Shades: West Elm

Shop

Dimensions: 20–50 inches wide; 48 66 84 inches long | Color: Sky blue | Material: Polyester rayon | Mounting type: Inside or out | Design: Cordless blackout

What we like: Broad custom width options

Fair-Trade Certified™ and handcrafted collections

Easy-to-navigate website Worth noting: Relatively pricey

Why we chose it: West Elm’s original designs are synonymous with quality.

You can be fairly certain that what you buy from West Elm is a signature design; 95 percent of its products are made in-house. The blinds selection is sustainably sourced with recycled and upcycled materials and custom-made options up for grabs. While selecting your blinds if you’re also in the market to shop for other accessories West Elm’s “pairs well with” feature is like an automated designer of sorts helping you pull together cohesive looks with ease. For advice that is more tailored to your needs there are designers one button-click away too. We love that the store offers a 30-day return policy but keep in mind that doesn’t apply to custom-made items.

Best Inexpensive Light-Blocking Blinds: IKEA

Shop

Dimensions: 64 inches wide; 23–48 inches long | Color: Blue | Material: Polyester | Mounting type: Wall or ceiling | Design: Roll-down; room darkening

What we like: Great price points

Products searchable by photo Worth noting: Limited colors

Why we chose it: What’s not to love about a one-stop shop for home goods?

We appreciate IKEA’s ongoing commitment to sustainability and when you combine that with products that won’t totally wipe out your budget you can’t go wrong. If you’ve ever been disappointed by a fruitless search for blinds on your “want” list you’ll be glad to discover IKEA’s photo-search option that can locate products with ease (shopping is supposed to be fun!).

Need tips on how to hang those gorgeous room-darkening shades? Tap a design expert on the retailer’s site for a virtual consultation and spend less time toiling over mounting options when you should be getting quality shut-eye with your new window coverings installed.

Best Linen Shades: Pottery Barn

Shop

Dimensions: 26-by-64 inches 32-by-64 inches 36-by-64 inches 44-by-64 inches 48-by-64 inches| Color: Navy | Material: Linen-cotton blend | Mounting type: Inside or outside | Design: Roller cordless

What we like: Sustainably sourced

Designer collaborations

Broad range of minimalist designs Worth noting: Limited color palette

Limited sizes

Why we chose it: Shop your favorite big-brand names at Pottery Barn.

With collaborators like Monique Lhuillier Sherwin-Williams and Disney Pottery Barn is your go-to for all things classic. For deMañana the retailer’s patterned linen selection is a personal favorite. Pottery Barn’s linen shades are on the pricier side but they are sharp. For the minimalist these understated window treatments quietly elevate a space—and they’re easily shoppable. You can opt for custom or off-the-rack picks and next select your fabric preference from Belgian flax to Emery linens. Lastly choose among light-filtering blackout cordless or a customized combination of any of the above.

Best Inexpensive Paper Blinds: Target

Shop

Dimensions: 36-by-72 inches | Color: White | Material: Paper | Mounting type: Self-adhesive | Design: Horizontal cordless pleated

What we like: Inexpensive

Easily shoppable website

Tons of cost-friendly linen options Worth noting: Limited high-end options

Why we chose it: A serviceable spot with an array of budget-friendly finds.

If you visit Target and manage to only leave with planned purchases we need you to teach us your ways. Seriously it’s beyond tempting to not fill your cart with everything in sight and shopping the store’s window accessories selection is no exception. DeMañana likes that Target has practical cost-friendly home decor options including these no-frills peel-and-stick light-filtering paper shades. For those who like to dress their windows with a bit more flair there are blinds and shades for that too (see the brand’s collections from Opalhouse designed with Jungalow and Threshold).

Click “add to cart” as many times as you’d like (don’t say we didn’t warn you) and either retrieve your order in store or use the app for contact-free curbside pickup.

Best Custom Wood Blinds: Smith & Noble

Shop

Dimensions: 9–102 inches wide; 12–120 inches long | Color: Walnut | Material: Wood | Mounting type: Inside | Design: Valance

What we like: Multiple slat sizes available

Customized dimensions

Reasonably priced Worth noting: Smart hub and remote-control upgrades

Why we chose it: Smith & Noble has a library of shoppable looks to help inspire your inner designer.

Even when you have a strong idea in mind blinds shopping can still be a harrowing experience because of the extensive choices. But Smith & Noble’s Idea Gallery helps customers hone in on their favorites through more creative control and reasonable prices—wood blinds start at $109. Its visual library which shows window treatments styled in a variety of rooms contains a shoppable “get the look” feature for those who don’t quite know where to start or how to accessorize their blinds. Considering all of the customized details for wood blinds in particular (hidden hinges tilt mechanism smart technology options) this is an incredibly useful tool.

Best Solar Shades Texture: The Shade Store

Shop

Dimensions: Customizable | Color: Cantaloupe | Brand: Chilewich | Material: Mini basket weave | Mounting type: Inside or outside | Design: Solar

What we like: Custom measurements

Broad range of design features

Lots of fabrics Worth noting: Numerous options may be difficult to narrow down

Why we chose it: Design your solar panels down to the smallest detail at the Shade Store.

We took a deep breath before diving into the Shade Store’s inventory because the options are seemingly bottomless making this retailer an awesome source of shopping inspiration for window coverings. For solar shades alone you can choose from more than 150 eco-friendly materials. Consider having a design-minded shopping buddy as your second set of eyes to help narrow down your selection. However we loved how simple it is to find Shade Store’s collaborators on the site—deMañana was particularly thrilled to see Chilewich’s high-performance fabric offerings on the list.

The Shade Store has free measurements available along with step-by-step instructions but you can also schedule a consultation with a professional.

How We Chose These Products

When considering the best places to buy blinds we placed a lot of emphasis on a site’s design: Was it easy to navigate? Were the price points dimensions and other details clear and simple to find? How did interactivity enhance the shopping experience? The best shopper is a well-informed one and these companies clearly devoted extra time and resources to make sure they present their products with ease and essential details to narrow your search. Additionally we focused quite a bit on price—we didn’t want you to feel like high-end window treatments are the only way to beautifully decorate your space; sprucing up a room is possible without depleting your budget. Overall deMañana’s picks are heavily practical customizable and in some cases sustainably sourced too.

Our Shopping Checklist

Privacy and Light

Each of our selected retailers offers light-filtering or blackout blinds and shades. As deMañana points out you really don’t want a gap between the window and the shade if you’re looking to reduce sound heat or both. So it’s ideal to take advantage of a brand that offers customized options with a wide variety of width measurements to help fine-tune your privacy and light filtering to your liking.

Safety

If you’re a parent who is worried about safety pay attention to the cord style. Per WCMA standards custom cords should not be longer than 40 percent of the window height. By customizing length you can easily have blinds with shorter cords or you can go with cordless blinds that can be manually lifted and drawn shut. Electric window blinds (operated by remote) are another option to consider.

Versatility

There are endless possibilities when it comes to materials width and length cord options light filtering and the like—some smart alternatives even auto adjust according to the sun’s position so you don’t have to constantly open or close your blinds. Others connect to Wi-Fi and respond to remote or voice commands.

Cleaning and Maintenance

Before shopping decide how much effort you’re willing to put into the upkeep of your blinds or shades. Those made of cotton and linen are machine washable or can be professionally cleaned since both materials tend to shrink in the wash. For textures that require a little less maintenance consider bamboo or wood that only needs an occasional spot treatment or dusting.

Budget

Obviously custom options are going to cost more than off-the-shelf treatments so plan to spend more if this is the route you choose. We’ve noticed at least a $100 difference in the price between the two alternatives. But as our more practical (but still equally stylish) store selections indicate this doesn’t mean you can’t spruce up your windows with a more modest budget. Most of our options offer free shipping and free design consultations—and in at least one case (hi Blindster) free custom remakes are available.

Ask Domino

Q: Should blinds be lighter or darker than walls?

This depends on your personal style but deMañana weighed in with some expert style tips. “In most cases I’d say go lighter because most common blind colors are lighter due to light-filtering properties” she says. On the other hand there’s nothing stopping you from going darker. “If you have a blue wall with a slightly darker shade of blind in the same color family I think it would look cool.”

Q: Can I get blinds for bay windows?

Short answer: Yes. In fact we’ve seen this done beautifully—look at these displays from the Shade Store for inspiration.

Q: How much should blinds cost per window?

While simpler options like Target’s paper blinds can cost as low as $6 plan to spend at least $50 per window for something more durable. Customized blinds can run upwards of $100 per window.

Q: Which blinds are most popular?

Among fan favorites (and ours too) are roman blinds wood and cordless. Smart blinds and shades are also popular (easy open easy close) as well as roller shades thanks to their simplistic minimalist design.

Q: Can I install blinds myself?

Absolutely. The wonderful thing about mounting blinds yourself is you can choose styles based on your installation preferences. Simple peel-and-stick options are obviously the simplest to “mount.” In the event you prefer blinds that require hardware nearly all of the retailers we mentioned have step-by-step instructions to guide you through the process or can arrange in-home appointments so a professional can take the guesswork out of installation.

Q: Are vertical blinds difficult to fit?

This depends on the user’s experience but the steps are pretty straightforward: You choose between an inside mount (one that fits inside the window frame) or an outside mount which positions the blinds above the window and outside the frame. While taking measurements be sure that the area where your blinds will be hung is clear of obstructions so they can move up and down freely. Also use a stud finder to confirm that the window frame where you plan to mount the blinds can manage the load.

Q: How far should blinds be from the floor?

The general consensus among experts is that vertical and horizontal blinds should hang 2 to 3 inches from the floor. To get this measurement add 2 to 3 inches to the total length between the floor and the molding or top of the window for an inside mount; for an outside mount add 2 to 3 inches above the window.

The Last Word

When it comes to the best places to buy blinds it doesn’t have to be a one-size-fits-all scenario. Figure out your budget your style preferences and which details you can live with (or can’t live without) and enjoy tapping into your inner designer while dressing your windows in top-notch decor.

Name: Dover Corporation
Name_1: Beaumont: We're peaking at the right time
Text_1:
England and Kent batter Tammy Beaumont insists her side are peaking at the right time ahead of their crucial final group stage game against Bangladesh at the ICC Women’s Cricket World Cup 2022.

A fourth straight win will secure England’s passage to the semi-finals and mark an incredible turnaround after a hat-trick of losses looked like ending the defending champions’ title defence at the first hurdle.

Kent and England's Tammy Beaumont. Picture: Keith Heppell

There is no shortage of motivation for Heather Knight’s side who know that a big win against Bangladesh will help improve their net run rate and give them a good chance of finishing third and avoiding table-toppers Australia who won seven from seven in the group stage in the knockout phase.

“I think we obviously started a little bit slow in the comp but our bowlers are certainly peaking at the right time” said opener Beaumont from Dover.

“Katherine Brunt looked in really good rhythm last game Kate Cross throughout has been brilliant Sophie Ecclestone too and everyone's chipping in where they can.

“With the batting we haven't had that solid opening partnership yet. We haven't got past 31 so it was good to see Danni (Wyatt) go on and get some good runs last game.

“And there's been contributions throughout. I do feel like we're starting to get there and play our best cricket as we come into the back end of this tournament.”

Beaumont was the Player of the Tournament at the ICC Women’s Cricket World Cup 2017 as her 410 runs helped fire England to glory on home soil.

This time around she is still averaging 35 despite her last three knocks against Pakistan New Zealand and India totalling just 28 but Beaumont is not the slightest bit concerned about her form.

She explained: “I don't really feel like I'm out of form. I think it was only a few games ago I scored 50 against South Africa.

“So I think when the games come thick and fast you're never far away from a good performance. I felt pretty good in some of the games and got some good balls so I'm not too worried.”

Kent's Tammy Beaumont will open the batting for England in Wellington. Picture: Ady Kerry

Bangladesh gave Australia a scare after reducing the world No.1 side to 70-5 in pursuit of 136 before Beth Mooney’s unbeaten 66 ensured the 2013 champions topped the group stage with a perfect seven wins.

And Beaumont is wary about what surprises the Bangladesh spin attack could have in store for her side on what will be another windy Wellington day particularly as the sides square off for the first time in ODIs.

She added: “They got a few early wickets against Australia so it's going to be really key to start working against them.

“They don't bowl with that much pace and they've got a lot of spinners. So that's going to be a challenge and particularly here at Wellington.

“It looks like it's going to be really windy one way hitting into the wind. So we have to be very smart with that.”

Bangladesh captain Nigar Sultana revealed her side are not planning to let England sweep their way out of trouble against their slow bowlers with off-spinner Salma Khatun in red-hot form having ripped through Australia’s fabled top three of Alyssa Healy Rachael Haynes and Meg Lanning at the same venue on Friday.

She said: “We plan for each individual team every time. We have a good spin attack so we are going to plan against them and not let them play the kind of shots they are used to playing.

“Obviously our bowling unit so far is doing well so I'm hoping they will do the same thing.”

Nigar admits she is hoping her batters come good against England as Bangladesh who cannot make the semi-finals aim to exit the tournament with a final flourish at the Basin Reserve.

She added: “What we did against Australia was like a bowlers’ show. I am hoping that the top order will also bounce back in tomorrow’s game.

“It’s the last game and we want to take all the positives back home.”

© ICC Business Corporation FZ LLC 2022

Name: Dow
Name_1: 3 Dow Stocks That Can Turn $300000 Into $1 Million by 2030
Text_1:
These well-known profitable and time-tested Dow components can make you a millionaire by the turn of the decade.

In two months the iconic Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI 0.46%) will celebrate its 126th "birthday." Since its founding in May 1896 it's evolved from a 12-stock industrial-dominated index to one that now houses 30 highly successful and diverse multinational companies.

It's also an index full of stocks that have a rich history of making patient investors money. Over the next eight years three Dow stocks stand out as having a good chance to outperform their peers. If you invest $300000 into these Dow components now they have the tools and intangible needed to potentially make you a millionaire by 2030.

Salesforce

The Dow stock I feel most confident about increasing in value by 233% over the next eight years is cloud-based customer relationship management (CRM) software solutions provider Salesforce.com (CRM 0.72%). Salesforce has averaged an annual gain of nearly 27% for shareholders since March 2005. In other words it doubles on average every 2.7 years.

CRM software is used by consumer-facing businesses to enhance existing customer relationships and boost sales. Some of the more common tasks businesses utilize CRM software for include overseeing online marketing campaigns handling product and service issues and running predictive sales analyses. The latter can be particularly helpful in determining which clients would be likeliest to purchase a new product or service.

As you might have guessed CRM software is geared toward the service industry. However it's made inroads in the financial healthcare and industrial sectors in recent years. CRM software is fully expected to offer low double-digit annual global growth potential through at least mid-decade if not beyond.

Salesforce slots in as the undisputed No. 1 of global CRM spending. According to a report from IDC Salesforce accounted for almost 24% of global CRM spend in the first-half of 2021. By comparison its four-closest competitors in market share didn't even add up to 20% on a combined basis. Salesforce is the go-to CRM solutions provider and is unlikely to cede significant share anytime soon.

It's also a company that's benefited immensely from inorganic growth. CEO and founder Marc Benioff has made a number of amazing acquisitions including MuleSoft Tableau Software and Slack Technologies. These deals not only expand the company's sales channels but they allow Salesforce to reach a broader audience of small-and-medium-sized businesses with their ecosystem of solutions.

Benioff is forecasting a near-doubling in full-year sales by mid-decade ($50 billion in fiscal 2026) making Salesforce the fast-growing Dow component investors should want to own.

UnitedHealth Group

Another Dow stock that can turn a $300000 investment into $1 million by 2030 is insurance and healthcare solutions giant UnitedHealth Group (UNH 0.39%). Over the past 25 years UnitedHealth has averaged an annual return of around 19%. If we include dividends this average annual return jumps to about 20%. This means the company has been doubling investors' money on average every 3.6 years.

UnitedHealth is probably best known for its insurance segment. Even though health insurance tends to be a relatively slow-growing operating model it's very profitable. Insurance companies are typically able to pass along higher premiums to counteract rising costs.

Aside from strong premium pricing power UnitedHealth can continue to benefit from the existence of the Affordable Care Act (ACA)(sometimes referred to as "Obamacare"). Despite the ACA requiring insurers to accept people with pre-existing conditions it also encouraged a lot of healthier people to purchase insurance as well.

However the real growth driver for UnitedHealth Group is its healthcare services subsidiary Optum. Optum has three segments of its own which provide everything from pharmacy prescription refills to data analytics and software to healthcare organizations. Optum has consistently grown faster than the insurance segment and it generally produces higher margins too. Thanks mostly to Optum Wall Street's consensus estimate calls for UnitedHealth to grow its full-year sales from $287.6 billion in 2021 to more than $497 billion by 2026. That's incredible sales growth for a megacap company.

At its current growth trajectory I believe UnitedHealth Group has the potential to more than triple its earnings per share by 2030 to north of $60 which in turn should send its shares a lot higher.

Visa

A third and final Dow stock with the ability to turn $300000 into $1 million by 2030 is payment processor Visa (V 1.56%). Over the trailing 14 years Visa has averaged an annual total return including dividends paid of around 21%. This means it's doubled investors' money on average every 3.4 years.

The most logical reason to buy Visa is the company's cyclical ties. In short it does well when the U.S. and global economy are expanding and it struggles a bit during recessions when consumers and businesses don't spend as much. The thing is recessions typically last for a few months or a couple of quarters whereas periods of economic expansion are usually measured in years. Visa is the type of company that allows patient investors to take advantage of the natural long-term expansion of the U.S. and global economy.

But let's be clear it also doesn't hurt that Visa controls a majority of credit card market share by network purchase volume in the U.S. -- the largest market for consumption in the world. Between 2009 and 2018 no payment processor saw a bigger jump in U.S. network purchase volume share than Visa. In fact Visa's 53.1% share in 2018 was 31 percentage points higher than its next-closest competitor.

Additionally Visa has a long runway with which to expand its payment infrastructure. It can do so via acquisition as it did with Visa Europe in 2016 or it can organically push into underbanked markets such as the Middle East Africa and Southeastern Asia. With much of the world still reliant on cash for transactions Visa looks to be sitting on a multidecade opportunity.

Lastly take into consideration that Visa purely acts as a payment processor and not a lender. Although lending would allow the company to reap the rewards of interest income and fees during long periods of economic expansion it would also expose it to loan delinquencies during recessions. Not lending means not having to set aside capital to cover delinquencies. This is why Visa bounces back quicker than virtually all other financial stocks following a recession or economic contraction.
Name_2: Passing The Helm on the La Dow Family Etchells
Text_2:
The Etchells fleet gets off the line at the Helly Hansen Sailing World Regatta Series in San Diego. Paul Todd/Outside Images

Second Wind may be just the perfect name possible for the La Dow family Etchells. Back in his heyday at San Diego YC father Andy was a standout sailor particularly in the local Etchells fleet and always a top finisher in the big fleets of years past including three class wins in the Helly Hansen Sailing World Regatta Series in San Diego. While dad was excelling in the elegant and cranky keelboat his two sons Jake and Will were doing the same in the Sabots and then 420s and onward to college where they too had standout careers.

And while this was happening later in life dad got busy in the real estate business and the Etchells eventually sat idle on its trailer collecting pollen and Santa Ana dust. The pandemic winds would blow Will home from San Francisco to San Diego the young software salesman now able to work remotely. Will says racing with his father was something they’d discussed for a long time but only when he moved back to San Diego did they consider it more seriously. And soon enough the three of them would find themselves together shoulder to shoulder on the side deck of the family Etchells its long and pointy bow rising and falling over humping Pacific swells. The boat had sat for three years and here they were together for the first time a new team who’s chemistry is simply its blood.

Their first event would be the 2021 Etchells Pacific Coast Championship. Will would skipper dad would handle the bow. “It all went well” was dad’s assessment. “The takeaway was that we had some potential here.”

Advertisement

Potential indeed: With an older boat desperate for the latest upgrades and a set of outdated rags they won their second regatta (without Jake however who was off racing J/70s). “My biggest concern was time in the boat” La Dow says “but I quickly realized we were going to be a force to be reckoned with right out of the gates.”

An lo-and-behold they absolutely enjoy sailing with each other.

“I will say it is a privilege to be able to sail with my dad on the boat” says La Dow. “It’s cool that we’ve both had success in sailing separately and can now do it together. Through sailing we are both able to compete at a high level and spend some quality bonding time together. There have been times where we’ve been in a tough spot [on the racecourse] where it may not feel like bonding but we always enjoy it.”

Advertisement

In the three years since the La Dows packed away Second Wind much has changed with the infinitely tunable Etchells—mast setup sail design and especially control systems—so the task at hand is for them to get the boat up to snuff. With so many top-shelf teams operating out of the San Diego YC boat park these days there’s knowledge and sharing aplenty says young La Dow.

“The fleet is really open these days and welcoming to new people that join the fleet. At the last event Chris Busch (fleet captain) hosted a debrief with all the top guys and got them to share what’s working—all these different things that in the past would be very secretive among certain boats. It’s been democratized across the fleet to get the level up so there’s more competition and the racing is more challenging and enjoyable.”

The La Dow’s Second Wind is hull No. 985 is considered an older boat. “But the hull seems fast enough” La Dow says. They’ve been working with local a local boat servicing company run by Chuck Eaton and Patrick Powell which specializes in upgrading Etchells. They’ve add a jib in-hauler system a mainsheet fine tune a mast ram and shims and an above-deck adjustable forestay.

Advertisement

“We’ve had to move quite a bit of hardware” La Dow says. “It was a bit of work but it’s done and ready to go.”

For the 2022 Helly Hansen Sailing World Regatta in March they will sail four-up with La Dow’s longtime mate and multi-national champion Scott Sinks as well as a pickup junior from the club.

Everyone was excited when the La Dows came back to the fleet and Will is doing his best to lure his peers and sailing buddies into the class. “It’s a really fun boat to sail” he says. “It is kind of like a keelboat version of the Club 420 as far as driving it and it’s fun to be able to get out of the small boats and do some open ocean racing.”
Name_3: Legendary stock picker Peter Lynch made a remarkably prescient market observation in 1994
Text_3:
Peter Lynch (Source: CSPAN )

[ NOTE: There will be no newsletter on Sunday April 3. TKer will be on vacation .]

Peter Lynch the legendary stock picker who ran Fidelity’s market-beating Magellan Fund for 13 years made a prescient observation in a speech he gave to the National Press Club back in October 7 1994.

It comes from the 38-minute mark of this video (via @DividendGrowth):

Some event will come out of left field and the market will go down or the market will go up. Volatility will occur. Markets will continue to have these ups and downs. … Basic corporate profits have grown about 8% a year historically. So corporate profits double about every nine years. The stock market ought to double about every nine years. So I think — the market is about 3800 today or 3700 — I'm pretty convinced the next 3800 points will be up; it won't be down. The next 500 points the next 600 points — I don’t know which way they’ll go. So the market ought to double in the next eight or nine years. They’ll double again in eight or nine years after that. Because profits go up 8% a year and stocks will follow. That's all there is to it.

When he says “the market” Lynch is referring the Dow Jones Industrial Average which closed at 3797 on the day he gave the talk.

If you compound that by an 8% growth rate over 27.5 years which would get you to present day then you get 31520.

The Dow closed Friday at 34861 which is pretty darn close. For context a 7% growth rate would’ve gotten you to 24405 and a 9% rate would’ve gotten you to 40613.

If you did this exercise with the S&P 500 which closed at 455 on the day of Lynch’s talk then you’d get 3778 assuming an 8% compound annual growth rate. The S&P closed Friday at 4543. (A 9% rate would’ve gotten you to 4867.)

According to S&P Dow Jones Indices S&P 500 earnings per share (EPS) were $30.11 for the 12 months ending Q3 1994 around the time Lynch gave that speech. If you compounded that by 8% over 27.5 years you’d get $250. S&P Dow Jones Indices estimates EPS for the 12 months ending March 2022 was actually $211 which is close. (They estimate S&P EPS will be $246 in 2023.)

Lynch was not predicting the precise point of the market in March 2022. He was talking about how markets trend over longer-term periods while acknowledging short-term volatility. If you allow him some margin of error to account for unpredictable short-term swings then you may be able to better appreciate how his thoughts speak to some fundamental market truths we often talk about here at TKer.

I think three elements of what Lynch said are critical for investors to understand.

1: ‘Some event will come out of left field and the market will go down or the market will go up. Volatility will occur.‘

This relates to TKer stock market truth No. 8: “The most destabilizing risks are the ones people aren’t talking about.“

Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is a good example. For investors a conflict between Russia and Ukraine had not been a concern so markets weren’t prepared for it. This would explain why stocks went into a deep correction amid the initial news and buildup.

With these types of unforeseen events prices will swing wildly as markets digest every positive and negative development as the situation unfolds.

This stands in contrast to the risks everyone has been talking about like inflation and tighter monetary policy. These risks had investors concerned for months before those fears were confirmed and the actual news eventually had a limited effect on market volatility.

2: ‘I’m pretty convinced the next 3800 points will be up; it won't be down. The next 500 points the next 600 points — I don’t know which way they’ll go.‘

Over time the stock market’s biggest moves will be to the upside (which relates to TKer stock market truth No. 4) and the long game is undefeated (which is TKer stock market truth No. 1.) But you can certainly get smoked in the short term (TKer stock market truth No. 2).

As we discuss frequently here on TKer big sell-offs are actually pretty normal. The S&P 500 experiences an average max drawdown (i.e. the biggest intra-year sell-off) of 14% a year.

For what it’s worth the current market correction has seen the S&P 500 fall 12% from its high of 2022 which is less bad than average.

Lynch’s comment speaks to the advantage of a long-term investment horizon which is a valuable edge most investors have.

Share

3: ‘Profits go up 8% a year and stocks will follow. That's all there is to it.’

The stock market has historically usually gone up because earnings have usually gone up. That’s because earnings are the most important driver of stock prices which is TKer stock market truth No. 5.

Check out this chart of S&P 500 earnings since 1986 courtesy of Yardeni Research. It’s on a logarithmic scale which smooths out the curve you get when growth is compounding at a steady rate over time.

There’s some short term noise. But over time earnings have been going up and to the right.

Jurrien Timmer director of global macro at Fidelity Investments recently shared a chart showing the tight relationship between earnings and stock prices.

Stock prices are on the y-axis accompanied by earnings on the x-axis. The data goes back all the way to 1871. The r-squared of 0.9686 in this linear regression is very close to 1 which means earnings do an extremely good job of explaining how stock prices behave.

In other words stocks go where profits go.

“That's all there is to it” Lynch said.

-

More from TKer:

Share
Name_4: New report finds almost 80% of active fund managers are falling behind the major indexes
Text_4:
More than three-quarters of active mutual fund managers are falling behind the S&P 500 and the Dow  a new report finds.

The S&P Indices versus Active (SPIVA) scorecard which tracks the performance of actively managed funds against their respective category benchmarks recently showed 79% of fund managers underperformed the S&P last year. It reflects an 86% jump over the past 10 years.

S&P Global CEO Doug Peterson told CNBC's "ETF Edge" the quarterly report is built on non-public information.

"The only people who have access to it have very strict rules about their own standards of performance and behavior" Peterson said last week. "[The S&P Dow Jones Indices committee] is able to look at the economy as a whole or look at different aspects of what they want to have the index perform against."

The corporation has been releasing its annual SPIVA report since 2002. First it was focused on the U.S. and later was extended to countries across the globe.

The latest report marks 12 consecutive years the average actively managed large-cap fund underperformed the S&P 500 noted Todd Rosenbluth CFRA senior director of ETF and mutual fund research.

"It's hard to outperform" Rosenbluth said on "ETF Edge." "It costs more for active managers when they're trying to compete with the S&P 500 that is essentially free through the ETF wrapper."

Disclaimer
Name_5: 7 Burger Joints on the Westside of LA Will Make You Forget About In-N-Out
Text_5:
From Vegan Patties to Classic Creations Here’s Where to Go When You Just Need a Really Good Burger

While it’s expected to find some of the freshest seafood on the westside of Los Angeles you may be surprised to learn that you can also find some of the best burgers. From West Hollywood to Santa Monica the westside has everything from beachside burger joints to 70s-inspired retro diners. Whether it’s a vegan burger or a juicy American classic these seven burger joints on the westside are sure to give In-N-Out a run for their money. Best Burgers Westside LA

Looking to cure your craving with the cleanest ingredients? HiHo Cheeseburger prides itself on being the only burger restaurant to exclusively serve 100% grass-fed wagyu beef. The onion jam on their HiHo Cheeseburger adds a savory yet sweet kick and the house-made pickles are the perfect amount of sour. Double the flavor by adding pastrami on top of any of their burgers (highly recommended) and don’t miss out on their from-scratch all-natural ice cream shakes.

Locations: Santa Monica and Marina Del Rey

Best Burgers Westside LA

Credit: The Win~Dow Credit: The Win~DowThe Win~Dow Credit: The Win~Dow Credit: The Win~Dow

The Win-Dow is a Venice staple that you need to check out while cruising the boardwalk. Their traditional smash burgers are legendary and they are all served with a secret house sauce that you’ll want to drizzle on literally everything. The Win-Dow’s burgers are hand-shaped and flat-top grilled making them thinner and easier to bite into. Order your meal to-go and grab a fresh lemonade before snagging a spot on the sand for a seaside picnic.

Location: Venice

6/19

Credit: Aaron Haxton Credit: Aaron Haxton Credit: Aaron Haxton Credit: Aaron Haxton

Ever fantasized about a vegan version of McDonald’s? Well Mr. Charlie’s is here to make all of your plant-based dreams come true. Located on the outskirts of West Hollywood Mr. Charlie’s serves everything from plant-based chicken nuggets to vegan cheeseburgers all inspired by the traditional style and flavors found at McDonald’s. If you want to try a bit of everything “turn your frown upside down” with their $15 meal.

Location: West Hollywood (or Fairfax District)

Best Burgers Westside LA

View this post on Instagram A post shared by Monty’s Good Burger (@montysgoodburger)

With locations all over LA Monty’s Good Burger has certainly made a name for itself among LA’s vegans and carnivores. The Impossible Meat patties could seriously fool even the most devout of meat-eaters while the potato buns boast a soft melt-in-your-mouth texture. Instead of fries go for their Max’d Out Tots and finish off your meal with a Rico’s root beer float which is sure to bring you back to your childhood.

Local Insight: Looking to adopt a furry family member? Monty’s works with the LA Animal Services to host an adoption drive once a month!

Location: Culver City

Credit: Danny Gordon Credit: Danny Gordon Credit: Danny Gordon

Between the homemade buns and premium sourced short rib Heavy Handed has earned a reputation for having some of the best burgers in all of LA. This casual food truck creates mind-blowing flavor combos and places a focus on the art of searing their meat to perfection. Regardless of how many patties you get on your short rib burger do yourself a favor and order an extra side of Heavy Sauce.

Location: Food truck (various locations; check website for details)

Best Burgers Westside LA

Credit: Jakob Layman Credit: Josh Telles Credit: Josh Telles Credit: Josh Telles

From Michelin-starred chef David Meyers Adrift Burger Bar serves signature burgers with an upscale flair. Inspired by flavors around the globe this laid-back burger bar features minimalistic decor in a beachy setting. Their cheesy Adrift Burger is coated in rich gruyere making the house-made truffle chips the perfect pairing. Also don’t skip on their “grown-up” shakes which are just as beautiful and boozy as they are decadent.

Location: Venice

Located in a cool retro diner off of Melrose nomoo takes vegan burgers to the next level. Everything is 100% vegan from the handspun shakes to the juicy patties. The BBQ “Facon” features a gourmet brioche bun with house-made “bacon” but the secret BBQ sauce is what really makes this flavor-packed burger stand out. Pro tip: load your fries “animal style” for the ultimate treat.

Local Insight: 10% of all proceeds at nomoo are donated to local charities allowing you to fill your belly and your heart.

Location: West Hollywood

Name_2: Pensacola Beach water rescues doubled in 2021 likely to rise in 2022
Text_2:
A post-pandemic rush to the beaches doubled the number of water rescues for 2021 and 2022 is shaping up to be just as busy if not busier.

Pensacola surfer and boat captain Mike Davis has seen the issue first-hand.

On March 18 while driving out to Orange Beach Alabama to surf Davis wound up rescuing two children from the Gulf.

Davis told the News Journal that the two children were visiting from Georgia and swimming in the Gulf close to sunset. Rip currents quickly pulled them from waste-deep water near the shoreline far out to sea.

More like this:Good Samaritan rescues four people onboard vessel that caught fire on Pensacola Bay

In case you missed it:Perdido Key woman kept husband with severed leg alive for 40 minutes until help arrived

He heard the youngest child a boy about 8 or 9 years old — the same age as his son — yell out muffled cries of "help me" through the waves.

After taking turns helping bring the boy and his sister back to the shore Davis said he felt more exhausted than any marathon he had ever run.

"I was exhausted. I still had to swim against the rip and I was questioning if I was going to make it to the beach myself" Davis later wrote in a Facebook post about the incident.

Davis said he returned to the coastline only to find out that the two kids were left to swim alone while family members waited back inside the Perdido Beach Resort.

Unfortunately incidents like this are seemingly occurring more frequently as people flock back to the beaches.

2022 shaping up to be one of Pensacola Beach's busiest rescue seasons

The 2021 season was one of the busiest Pensacola Beach lifeguards have seen in the past five years and Escambia County Water Safety Chief Dave Greenwood anticipates the 2022 season to be just as active.

March and April are the prime season for rip currents due to the powerful frontal winds that sweep over the Gulf of Mexico. It's common to start seeing several instances a week in which lifeguards need to either stop beachgoers from entering the water or are called out to make a rescue Greenwood said.

Sometimes other beachgoers step in to try to assist as Davis did but Greenwood cautioned that good-intentioned people can exacerbate the situation if they are also swept into the rip. The best course of action is to call 911 and let lifeguards fulfill their duty.

Greenwood said this exact situation occurred March 16 on Pensacola Beach as two water rescues doubled into four. He said Pensacola Beach lifeguards and Escambia County Fire Rescue rescued four swimmers who were swept into the current two of whom had gone in trying to save the first pair.

The incident required the help of Station No. 13's wave runners to reach the swimmers. Two of the swimmers were ultimately transported to a local hospital.

Spring break drives crowd to Pensacola:Pensacola Beach sees 'monster' spring break season. What's driving the bigger crowd?

Pensacola's famous beach ball repainted:What's happening to Pensacola Beach's famous beach ball? It's getting a makeover.

Greenwood said 80% of rescues are rip-current related.From 2017 to 2020 Pensacola Beach lifeguards averaged 250 active rescues each year but in 2021 they had more than double that with 529 rescues.

The number of people Pensacola Beach lifeguards have kept out of the water for safety reasons has also been rising over the past five years. They made contact with about 27000 in 2017 and that number rose to over 173000 last year.

How Pensacola Beach lifeguards are preparing

Greenwood said he plans to have an additional 43 lifeguards hired by the start of the summer season on Memorial Day. After Memorial Day lifeguards will also be allocated to different beaches throughout Gulf Islands National Seashore.

The safety flags put out every morning on the beach and announced on the Pensacola Beach Lifeguards Facebook page give people an indication of the conditions when going out to swim.

But Greenwood cautioned that swimming in the Gulf is much more difficult than swimming in still water due to the unpredictability of waves and marine life. Even the most experienced swimmers can have a difficult time facing the currents.

While there awareness signs plastered all over the beach perimeter it can still be hard to know exactly what to do when you're actually being swept out to sea by the tide. Even if it it’s difficult to see the break in the water indicating a rip current a scalloped shoreline can be an indicator.

“It’s easy to see on a graphic but not as easy when looking out at the water” Escambia County Public Safety Information Officer Davis Wood said. “Always approach a lifeguard and ask to show you where the safe spots are.”

Greenwood said lifeguards spend red-flag days patrolling the beach and keeping swimmers out of the water when currents are too strong. Greenwood said the lifeguards are extensively trained to use the current to their advantage swimming right into the line of danger and pulling victims back to shore.

Most drownings occur when the sun is out the surf is high or it’s a holiday: making the days leading around the Fourth of July holiday and the Blue Angels Air Show this year on July 9 a particularly dangerous time for potential drowning.

Updates about beach conditions can be found on Pensacola Beach conditions on the Pensacola Beach Lifeguards Facebook page or by calling 850-554-4301.
Name_3: This Company Has the Most Profits Per Employee
Text_3:
This Company Has the Most Profits Per Employee Scott Olson / Getty Images News via Getty Images

Companies with high profits and revenue per employee are presumed to be the most successful. Alphabet Microsoft and Meta Platforms owner of Facebook are such companies. These tech companies are among the largest in the United States based on revenue and they are among the youngest large companies. Several were founded in the past 25 years. However a group of relatively small companies leads the list of highest profit per employee.

Data for the recent “Profit per Employee” research paper from software company Tipalti came from the Fortune 500. The paper examined 914 major companies most of which made a profit per employee in the last year. Only 238 reported a loss per employee. The company that has the most profits per employee is Air Lease. The company reported $516 million in profits or $4.3 million per employee.

Air Lease with an employee count of 120 buys passenger planes and leases them to airlines. The process allows carriers that do not have capital access to planes. Air Lease makes its profit largely off the interest it charges these carriers. The company was hurt by the trouble with the aviation industry caused by the COVID-19 pandemic but its financials have started to recover.

When the company announced its 2021 results John L. Plueger chief executive officer and president commented: “We had a strong fourth quarter and second half of 2021 that benefited from continuing airline industry recovery as seen in our cash collections operating metrics fleet expansion and record lease placement.”

Air Lease owns 474 planes that it leases to 118 customers in 60 countries. The company is based in Los Angeles. (See if Air Lease is also among the 50 best companies to work for.)

To find the 50 companies with the most profits per employee 24/7 Wall St. reviewed Tipalti’s “Profit per Employee” research paper. Very few of the companies with the highest profit per employee are large tech companies. Meta is highest among these ranking 11th with a profit of nearly $500000 per employee based on over 58000 workers. Several financial firms are ahead of Meta.

Mortgage giant Fannie Mae has profit of $1.5 million per employee based on 7700 workers. This places it second on the list. The third is private equity firm KKR at $1.3 million per employee based on 1583 workers. (Find out if any of the companies on this list were also among the most innovative companies in 2021.)
