Name: General Mills
Name_1: Carin Schoppmeyer: Children’s Shelter supporters offer hope
Text_1:
Northwest Arkansas Children's Shelter champions gathered for the nonprofit organization's Starlight Gala March 5 at the Rogers Convention Center.

Emily McCord board president told those gathered that the shelter's mission is to "provide a safe haven high quality care and hope for the future for children who have been abandoned abused or neglected."

The 24-hour residential shelter a private nonprofit organization has served more than 12000 children from across Arkansas since its founding in 1993. Residents may stay up to 45 days within a six-month period until returning to their families or being placed in foster care.

In August 2020 the nonprofit organization opened an on-site school for non-residential students. The Hope Academy of Northwest Arkansas is a charter school open to shelter residents as well as "children throughout Northwest Arkansas who will benefit greatly from a trauma-informed educational setting."

In 2021 the shelter provided more than 40000 meals more than 30000 snacks 700 medical and dental appointments and 25 birthday parties -- one of which was a first for a 17-year-old.

Last year there were 4854 children in foster care -- an 11 percent increase from the previous year. Benton and Washington counties continue to rank among the highest across the state in substantiated cases of abuse and neglect McCord added.

The theme for the Starlight Gala was "What Hope Looks Like." McCord said: "Hope is the feeling that what is wanted can be had or that things will turn out for the best; to believe to desire to trust -- that is our goal for every child who comes through our doors."

McCord introduced Rebekah Mitchell new shelter executive director to event guests saying the board of directors had conducted a nationwide search for a leader who would help them fulfill their mission and that with Mitchell "we knocked it out of the park."

The evening helped raise nearly $400000 for the shelter which will augment the less than 20 percent of the shelter's operating budget received from the state.

Those championing the children's shelter and hope included Mike Klaas Susan and Miles Eason Molly and Eric Plummer Meredyth and Matt Malone Vanessa and Adam Morris Nicola King Katie and Jason Fremstad Emily and Blake McCord Luisa and Chris Lamson Nancy and Dick Trammel Diana and Kent Eikenberry Lori and Steve Collins and Patrick Bannon and Andrea Albright gala honorary chairwoman.

For more event photos -- nwadg.com/photos/society.

Columnist Carin Schoppmeyer can be reached by email at [email protected].

Name_3: These Grocery Foods Just Got More Expensive This Month
Text_3:
Grocery prices have been high for years now thanks to the pandemic supply chain problems and the recent sharp rise in the inflation rate only adds to the growing costs for shoppers. Ingredients used to make grocery store products are getting more expensive too and it's now being reflected on price tags at your favorite stores.

Several food brands are in charge of quite a few smaller names in lots of aisles and three have recently announced that in March they would be raising prices to combat inflation. Here are some of the specific products that have or will soon get another big price increase.

6 Things You'll See at Costco This Year

Mondelez Snacks like Oreos Chips Ahoy and More

Back when inflation was up by 7% at the beginning of the year Mondelez announced that it would raise the price of its products like Ritz Crackers Sour Patch Kids Chips Ahoy Oreos and more once again. The news came after it said in November 2021 it would raise prices in January 2022 by around 7% to offset inflation.

"[Suppliers] don't have enough for all their customers so they basically say you'll have to pay what I tell you to pay" Dirk Van de Put Mondelez's CEO told The Wall Street Journal. "It's all out of whack."

Oat Milk

The price of oats and other raw materials in addition to devastating harvests means that the oat milk brand Oatly is going to raise the prices of its products. CFO Christian Hanke detailed the plan in the company's recent earnings call saying that while shoppers in the U.S. will have until July to get Oatly products for the same price those in other parts of the world are already paying more.

"We are seeing higher costs raw materials logistics and energy globally as well as labor inflation. We are strategically taking price increases in EMEA and the Americas to help offset a portion of these higher costs" he said. "Price increases are already in effect in certain markets in [Europe the Middle East and Africa] and we will begin to see the benefit of price increases in the Americas starting in the second half of 2022."



To get all the latest grocery store news delivered right to your email inbox every day sign up for our newsletter!

This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Kraft Heinz products like Oscar Mayer Bacon and Velveeta

Kraft Heinz is taking a page from the same book and making the price of some of its staples at the grocery store go up between 5% and 30% in March. That amounts to over $1 more in some cases. Velveeta Fresh packs will go up 6.6% cold cuts and hot dogs by 10% Maxwell coffee by 5% Capri Sun and Kool-Aid options by 20% and Oscar Mayer Turkey Bacon by 30%.6254a4d1642c605c54bf1cab17d50f1e

The company announced the hikes in February through a letter to shoppers noting that the reasonings include "constrained supply logistic bottlenecks and weather-driven crop losses."

General Mills Products

General Mills manufacturers brands like Annie's Betty Crocker Cheerios Lucky Charm's Trix and more and is raising the price of them. The company began the process in mid-January according to CNN with some of the items being as much as 20% more.

In addition to upping its prices General Mills also says that products that have pizza dough may be hard to find on shelves. CFO Kofi Bruce admitted that the company is seeing "acute supply shortages" and is only able to produce enough Pillsbury and Totino's pizza rolls products for shoppers to find around 70% of the time.

Unfortunately these may be the tip of the iceberg as President Biden Warns 'Real' Grocery Shortages Are Coming.

Name_5: Perth Wildcats GM of Basketball Danny Mills opens up on John Brown III and Michael Frazier II’s import drama
Text_5:
Perth Wildcats General Manager of Basketball Operations Danny Mills has no regrets about trying to sign American John Brown III mid-season despite FIBA not giving the club a letter of clearance in time for him to play the minimum number of games required to qualify for finals.

The Wildcats will play Sydney at RAC Arena on Saturday without Brown after running out of time to get him cleared.

Name_3: A Look Back at Chevrolet's Iconic W Engine the First in a Long Line of Big-Blocks
Text_3:
Photo: General Motors LLC

Photo: General Motors LLC

Photo: General Motors LLC

Development of this legendary series kicked off in 1955 when engineers realized that the new 265 ci (4.3 liters) small-block V8 was not powerful nor reliable enough (under high-rpm usage) for the division’s future vehicles - specifically its trucks and larger passenger cars. A bigger motor was a must so the brightest engineering minds available in Chevy’s fold teamed up to create one. Many think that it was just a larger block version of the 265 but in fact the W featured a radically different design.Released in 1958 the engine was devised to be enlargeable for increased displacement applications as well as higher compression ratios but remained sufficiently compact (by 1950s standards) to fit inside the engine bays of passenger cars. The iron block’s decks were angled at 74 degrees from the crankshaft centerline while a wedge-shaped  16-degree combustion chamber stood between the top of each piston and the flat head face. This chamber design was inspired by the in-cylinder layout of the revolutionary 283-ci (4.6-liter) small-block introduced a year earlier.The 348-ci (5.7-liter) naturally-aspirated big-block was curiously dubbed Turbo-Trust and was originally conceived for trucks but as I mentioned before engineers were also aiming to use it on several passenger car models. To make it suitable for both applications they came up with a simple trick in the form of a relief groove was cut into the top of the cylinder wall. This feature was present on the blocks that were intended for trucks to help lower the compression ratio whereas those built for cars had conventional cylinder walls which together with various height piston dome configurations favored higher compression ratios.The 348 weighed about 125 pounds (56.7 kg) more than the 283 small-block but the added weight translated into a bombproof block with cylinders that ended up being almost invulnerable to pre-ignition.In terms of dimensions the Turbo-Thrust was 1.7 inches (4.3 cm) longer 3 inches (7.6 cm) wider and 0.80-inch (2 cm) lower than its small-block siblings so it was easy to install in Chevy cars such as the Impala Biscayne or Delray.With a four-barrel 450-cfm carburetor the base engine produced 250 hp. Next in line was the Super Turbo-Thrust that came with three two-barrel 225-cfm carbs. Under usual driving conditions only the center carburetor worked but when the gas pedal was pushed with real purpose a vacuum switch awoke the other two carburetors that improved power to 280 horses. The top 1958 version named Special Turbo-Thrust was equipped with a single four-barrel carb and was capable of 305 hp.For 1959 and 1960 high-output editions of the top two engines were produced with 320 hp and 335 hp respectively. 1960 also saw the introduction of a 315-hp Special Super Turbo-Thrust that was upgraded with mechanical lifters and triple two-barrel carburetors. In 1961 the last year of production for the 348 power was increased again to 340 hp for the single four-barrel and 350 hp for the triple-carb unit.For the 1961 model year Chevy unleashed a larger-displacement variant of the W-series. Bored and stroked to 409 ci (6.7 liters) it debuted in the Impala SS (Super Sport) with a single four-barrel carburetor and could produce 360 hp then 380 hp in 1962.A dual four-barrel version followed spitting out no less than 409 hp thus developing 1 hp per cubic inch. It had a forged steel crankshaft and a beefed-up aluminum intake. In 1963 output for this variant reached 425 hp thanks to a compression ratio of 11:1 and a solid lifter camshaft. The 409 was available through mid-1965 when it was replaced by the 396-ci (6.5-liter) Mark IV.The holy grail of the W-series was a special 427-ci (7.0-liter) version of the 409 that could be ordered with the drag-oriented Chevrolet Regular Production Option (RPO) Z11 for the 1963 Impala Sport Coupe. Conservatively rated at 430 hp this engine was fitted to only fifty Z11 Impalas.Although it was in service for less than a decade the W paved the way for a long line of Chevy big-blocks including the highly successful 427-ci (7.0-liter) Mark IV or its race-bred ZL1 sibling. Today both 348 and 409 versions are still around enjoying legendary status among the hot rod community for their reliability and ease of tuning. The list of aftermarket hardware still available for the W is so extensive that you can build one from scratch without requiring a single OEM component.If you would like to know more about this iconic powerplant we recommend the video below posted on YouTube by OldCarMemories.com.
Name_4: Lucid Motors Drives to Oscars as Many Car Advertisers Stay Away
Text_4:
One of the automobile sector’s newest players is making a big bet on the Oscars at a time when many other car manufacturers are staying away from the glitzy event.

Lucid Motors a manufacturer of luxury electric vehicles that believes it can compete with traditional auto companies like Mercedes-Benz has typically spent most of its TV-advertising money for around sports and news programming. On Sunday it will sponsor the Oscars an entertainment program for the first time part of a bid to get its name out to a broader audience. Disney’s ABC has been seeking between $1.7 million and $2.2 million for a 30-second ad in the show according to media buyers and executives and announced this week it had sold off all its commercial inventory around the event.

“We just felt there was a moment happening around entertainment and film again” after consumers spent the last two years hunkering down during the coronavirus pandemic says Jeff Curry Lucid’s vice president of marketing in an interview. “There are a lot of people now looking to go back to the movies.”

The company won’t find much traffic in its way. General Motors which has sponsored the Oscars for the past few years isn’t making an appearance on Sunday. And the only other auto advertiser that has disclosed its Oscars affiliation is Stellantis which owns Chrysler Dodge and Peugeot among other brands. Some big car advertisers have pulled back in recent months according to ad-sales executives and media buyers owing to supply-chain issues that are making the prospect of keeping their products coming off the assembly line a difficult one at best.

Popular on Variety

That gives Lucid time to tell its story. In a spot slated to run during the Oscars the company plans to show off its Lucid Air which it says gets 500 miles on a single charge and has been named Motor Trend’s 2022 car of the year. Viewers get to see the car’s dashboard and interior as well as its outer design. “It’s not beginner’s luck” says a female narrator.

“Talking about our product right now is the best single way we can tell people about who we are as a brand” says Curry. “You can see the design and the technology that’s in it.”

Lucid’s challenge notes Curry is that “we’re new.” Advertisers often use events like the Oscars to tell consumers about new products or innovations getting the word out to what is expected to be one of TV’s broadest audiences. Curry is aware the ABC broadcast has suffered in recent years from a significant decline in ratings — “maybe the ratings have not been quite as high as they have in the past” — but believes the decision to have this year’s program led by three female hosts at a moment when the nation hopes to recapture its old way of life will generate consumer interest. “We are hopeful it will be a really nice moment for the industry for entertainment in general for people to tune in.”

The introduction of electric vehicles by many of the industry’s biggest manufacturers has already spurred some bold advertising swings. General Motors took to the Super Bowl with commercials that convened the cast of the “Austin Powers” movie series and reunited members of the HBO drama “The Sopranos.” Ford Volvo and Hyundai are among the familiar names that have pledged to make more of a business in electric vehicles as consumers and governments grow more wary of the effects of climate change.

Lucid will also rely on some tactics that take place off screen. Orlando Bloom is supposed to be driving a Lucid Air around Los Angeles this weekend. And viewers might look for actor Kodi Smit-McPhee nominated for supporting actor for his work in “ Power of the Dog” to arrive at the Oscars on Sunday in a Lucid Air.

Name: Gilead Sciences
Name_1: Weekend
Text_1:
SPONSORED BY Analog Devices Subscribe Now New voices and visual storytelling that not only informs but inspires. Sign up now to receive EE Times Weekend. SUBSCRIBE The Neanderthal in Us Anne-Françoise Pelé When our ancestors Homo sapiens reached Europe between 56800 and 51700 years ago the continent was populated by Neanderthals. After thriving in Eurasia for over 300000 years Neanderthals vanished from the Earth about 40000 years ago. Why did they become extinct? What did humans inherit from Neanderthals? Could archaic genes help us fight diseases? Paleogeneticists at the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology in Leipzig Germany are on a mission to elucidate this prehistoric “cold case.” Image: Smithsonian National Museum of Natural HistoryJohn Gurche/Chip Clark The name Homo neanderthalensis was coined by geologist William King in 1864 after the first specimen of an early human fossil was discovered in the Feldhofer Cave of the Neander Valley in Germany (tal — a modern form of thal — means “valley” in German). Neanderthals are ancient relatives on the hominid family tree. According to Max Planck Institute geneticists modern humans and Neanderthals coexisted in western Europe for up to 5000 years and degrees of genetic traces from such encounters can still be found in the genome of people outside Africa. On average people living today carry between 1% and 2% Neanderthal DNA. Recent research led by Janet Kelso a computational biologist at the Max Planck Institute has shown that Neanderthal DNA influences variation in skin tone hair color sleep patterns (night cavers and bonfire partygoers you are covered!) and smoking behaviors (smokers blame your Ice Age ancestors!). Similarly segments of Neanderthal DNA found in modern humans would be responsible for the degradation of fats. By bringing together fossil skull data brain imaging and genomics an interdisciplinary research team led by the Max Planck Institute found that Neanderthal genes influence the brain development of modern humans. They affect the shape of the skull and the areas of the brain responsible for planning and coordinating movements. Researchers demonstrated the effects of this Neanderthal DNA on gene activity in the putamen a basal ganglion and in the cerebellum. Several genes that humans received from Neanderthals also play an important role in shaping our immune system. In 2020 researchers at the Karolinska Institutet in Sweden and the Max Planck Institute demonstrated that a segment of DNA that causes their carriers to have an up to 3× higher risk of developing severe Covid-19 is inherited from Neanderthals. Six months later the same team showed that Neanderthals also contributed a protective variant and half of all people outside Africa carry a Neanderthal gene variant that reduces the risk of needing intensive care for Covid-19 by 20%. During their research they also found that the same gene variant that increases the risk of falling seriously ill with Covid-19 reduces a person’s risk of contracting HIV by 27%. Whether it is genesis or genetics that underlies our thinking prehistoric legacy is invoked to draw lessons about who we essentially are. Analog Devices × EE Times RF Signal Chain Discourse: Properties and Performance Metrics Substantial understanding of fundamental characteristics for RF technologies that underpin any RF signal chain allows RF engineers to easily translate them into key requirements and specifications of the target application. In this paper we provide guidance on the main properties and metrics used to characterize RF devices and quantify the performance metrics associated with RF systems. READ NOW Let the Memory Live Again Brian Santo At a point in the future that might be nearer than many expect the industry is going to need an entirely new data storage medium to store hundreds of terabytes probably petabytes and maybe even exabytes. At the moment each of the three likeliest possibilities is more exotic than the next. They’re holograms 5D quartz and DNA. The relentlessly growing surge of data that must be transmitted processed and stored is a constant challenge. The industry anticipates that moving from electronics to photonics will be the path to growth in transmission throughputs and processing speeds but storing photons is not an option. So how to move beyond semiconductor memory? Holograms have been around for decades but holographic memory still needs quite a bit more R&D work. The basic concept is to store images in crystals. To read a beam is trained on the crystal and a high-res camera captures the image; the image data gets translated back into digital data. Multiple images can be stored in the same volume; change the angle of the beam to read different images. Lithium niobate crystals are rewriteable. The fundamental concept of 5D storage harks back to compact disks and DVDs. Recording CDs requires making physical pits on a flat medium. To read illuminate the surface with a laser. Is there a pit? Yes-or-no is one-or-zero. That’s 2D. DVDs work the same way but they have multiple layers. That’s 3D. The medium for 5D is a specialty quartz. A laser reader notes not just whether or not there’s a pit but also the optical property of birefringence. As the name suggests birefringence has two states. Now we’re at 5D. Developers say it’s possible to store eight bits in a single pit. If the technology can be perfected a 12-inch crystal platter could hold hundreds of terabytes and the medium would be stable for a thousand years. DNA storage leaves traditional electromechanics behind. DNA consists of strands of the amino acids adenine guanine cytosine and thymine (AGCT) which can be combined in endlessly variable order and can be correlated to binary digits (bits). Strands of AGCT can be assembled stored in liquid and read out. While 5D quartz can be expected to last a thousand years there’s an example of DNA being sequenced from the tooth of a mammoth that died a million years ago. By one estimate 4 grams of DNA could hold all the data the entire world could generate in one year. At the moment DNA storage is a lab curiosity exorbitantly expensive slow

and subject to errors from mutation – a novel consideration in electronics. That said the promise of unlimited storage volume and astonishing longevity of DNA has all of the biggest data center operators monitoring the technology. There are at least 20 organizations who say they can perform DNA storage. DNA storage companies have attracted over $1 billion in funding since 2020. Gene Therapy Isn’t Science Fiction Barbara Jorgensen If you know nothing else about genes you know that they are microscopic and complex and differentiate humans from amoebae. In addition to determining features such as hair and eye color in humans genes can also cause disease. Gene therapy seeks to correct defective genes to manage a variety of health conditions. Science fiction has had a field day with genetic manipulation — think “Jurassic Park” — but adding inhibiting editing or replacing genes are bona-fide medical treatments. Within a gene DNA can be modified to manage blood disorders vision loss cancer heart disease diabetes and cystic fibrosis. CRISPR is perhaps the best-known technology in the field: It’s a tool for editing genomes allowing researchers to easily alter DNA sequences and modify gene function. But in laboratories electronic equipment does a lot of the heavy lifting. Centrifuges incubators and freezers are typical lab instruments. Then there’s process automation which can increase sterility levels in fluid transfer and eliminate manual handling. A sample taken from a patient for example may be returned to that patient after it’s been processed. Sensor technology and analytics increase the scalability of equipment and therapies and reduce time and headcount. The first successful nuclear gene transfer in humans (approved by the National Institutes for Health) was performed in 1980. To date more than 2600 clinical trials in gene therapy have been conducted. China has become the dominant location for gene therapy trials due to the nation’s expanding research ecosystem and significant governmental support for emerging technologies. China is the only country in the top five — U.S. China U.K. Germany France — where non-industry sponsored trials outnumber industry-sponsored trials (73% versus 27%). One therapeutic success story centers around vision loss. Researchers identified a gene — RPE65 — associated with blindness and used a harmless virus to insert a healthy gene underneath a patient’s retina. In 2017 the U.S. FDA approved voretigene neparvovecrzyl (marketed as Luxturna) for the treatment of any heritable retinal dystrophy caused by the mutated RPE65 gene. The cell and gene therapy market was valued at $4.99 billion in 2021 according to research firm Arziton; the segment is forecast to reach $36.92 billion by 2027 with a CAGR of 39.6%. Key players are Gilead Sciences Novartis Smith Nephew Amgen Organogenesis Roche (Spark Therapeutics) Dendreon Vericel and Bristol-Myers Squibb. Why So Blue? Stefani Muñoz When I first adopted my puppy back in 2021 many of those around me inquired whether she was part chow. When I asked why they thought so they would say it was because part of her tongue was blue which is characteristic of the chow chow breed. One Embark DNA test later and lo and behold — my puppy was indeed part Chow. I then began to wonder why exactly chows have blue tongues while many other canine breeds don’t. It’s said that chows originated in China about 2000 years ago first appearing in Chinese artifacts dating as far back as 206 B.C. Many historians believe that chow chows were the inspiration behind the design of the stone lion statues that commonly guarded Buddhist temples and it’s said they were considered “war dogs” often named “man kou” meaning “dog of the Barbarians.” According to Chinese legend when Earth was created and the first stars were placed into the heavens parts of the sky fell to the earth. Chows deemed ever-curious creatures licked the blue pieces of sky from the ground staining their tongues deep blue. Other sources claim the breed’s blue-tinged tongues were inherited from bears. Turns out it comes down to their genetics — more specifically their pigment cells. Similar to humans a canine’s genetic code determines both the type and amount of pigment cells present depending on the genetic makeup of their parents. There are two primary pigments found within canines that determine not only the color of a dog’s tongue but also their eyes nose and so on: eumelanin and phaeomelanin. Eumelanin produces a black color while phaeomelanin produces a red color. It’s important to note however eumelanin determines the color of a canine’s nose tongue lips and eyes whereas phaeomelanin determines the color of fur. The reason behind chow’s blue tongues is the presence of excess eumelanin within the mucous membranes of their tongues. A deeply blue tongue is an indicator that a chow is purebred while only a partially blue tongue could indicate that the chow contains some other time of canine DNA. Chows aren’t the only dog to exhibit blue tongues nor the only mammal: Blue tongues are common in the Chinese Shar Pei Eurasier and Thai Ridgeback as well as polar bears giraffes and blue-tongued lizards. Enjoying EE Times Weekend? Sign up to receive your own copy of EE Times Weekend Edition every Saturday. SUBSCRIBE Denis Marcon: ‘Be Curious and Passionate About Your Work’ Denis Marcon received an M.S. degree from the University of Padova in 2006. Subsequently he received the degree of Doctor in Engineering (Ph. D.) from the Catholic University of Leuven and Imec with the thesis entitled “Reliability study of power gallium nitride based transistors” in 2011. He is leading author or co-author of more than 50 journal papers or international conference contributions. After his Ph.D. graduation he led projects aiming to develop GaN HEMTs for several applications in RF and power switching before joining the business development team of Imec. In this role he was directly responsible for Imec's partnerships in the field of GaN power electronics as well as development and manufacturing of Si-based devices MEMS sensors and microsystems. Today Denis is general manager of Innoscience Europe (a subsidiary of Innoscience) and is directly responsible for Innoscience’s GaN business and marketing in Europe and the USA. What personal projects will you be working on this weekend Denis? I am currently working on a project with my 11 year-old son that involves building up and programming a mini-robot. Sometimes I actually think I am more into it and excited to see the mini-robot moving under our instructions than my son is. How do you talk about technology with your kids? Together with them I like to disassemble electronic devices and explain to them the components inside and their high level functions (e.g. camera microprocessor power devices and so on). By means of electronic kits for kids I also show them how electronics works. It’s great fun and educational too. Who was (or is) your mentor? I had several leaders and mentors in my career. I was taught how to be an inspirational leader and I was taught the importance of building up true relationships that go beyond business. This mentor taught me not to accept any easy explanation and more importantly to always question results. Who is your favorite musician writer or artist? I like all types of music with a strong preference towards (hard) rock music and particularly [Italian rockstar] Vasco Rossi Queen Iron Maiden Metallica… you could say I like energetic music. What is the biggest threat to society posed by technology today? I think the biggest threat posed by technology today is to lose the human contact and interaction which is increasingly being substituted by virtual interactions. It is something we need to be mindful of. What advice would you give to early-career engineers? Firstly I’d say they need to be curious and passionate about their work… or to ensure they only work on what they are curious and passionate about. It might sound like a cliché yet that is what moves me and that is what makes me go the extra mile… without feeling as though it was a chore. I am fascinated passionate and almost in love with GaN semiconductor technology – and what you can make with it. A second piece of advice is to listen: listen to the market listen to your customers listen to your fellows etc… and adapt accordingly. My third piece of advice would be to make plans of what you want to do and achieve (both at a high level and a low level) get to work and get things done. Reimagining the Vehicle of the Future The perfect way to round up the week EE Times On Air offers thirty minutes of audio journalism every Friday on the week's most compelling stories in electronics. On the Weekly Briefing podcast this week: Electrification is giving automakers an opportunity to completely reimagine what a car is and what it can be. A conversation exploring new trends and challenges on the road to vehicle electrification with Ryan Manack director of Automotive Systems Worldwide at Texas Instruments. Listen Now Inspiring New Ideas. For expert takes and the joy of discovery every Saturday sign up today.
